cards.front:
Which step in EMS decision making comes after a patient has been transferred?

A. Team communication
B. Planning
C. Outcome evaluation
D. Data gathering
See Critical Thinking and Clinical Decision Making in EMS

In an interdependent group, when one person fails:

A. that person is fired.
B. pay is withheld.
C. management will be changed.
D. everyone fails.
See Dependent, Independent, and Interdependent Groups

When working as an independent health care group member, the EMT should expect that he or she:

A. does not have to wait for an assignment before performing a task.
B. will be specifically instructed on how to perform a specific task.
C. will rely on the group leader for making virtually all decisions.
D. will receive no support or guidance from an EMS supervisor.
See Dependent, Independent, and Interdependent Groups
cards.back: does not have to wait for an assignment before performing a task.

cards.front:
EMTs and other health care providers function as a true team when they work:

A. interdependently.
B. dependently.
C. under standing orders.
D. independently.
See Dependent, Independent, and Interdependent Groups

EMTs arrive at the scene of an ill person. The EMR, who arrived before the EMTs, advises that the patient had a syncopal episode. The patient is conscious and alert and remains so throughout transport. When transferring patient care to the emergency department nurse, the EMT should advise the nurse that:

A. there is no evidence to support the syncopal episode.
B. the EMR was probably mistaken about the episode.
C. the patient had a reported syncopal episode.
D. she should contact the EMR about the incident.
See Transfer of Patient Care
cards.back: the patient had a reported syncopal episode.

cards.front:
While caring for a patient, the EMT states to her partner, “Why even splint the patient’s leg if they’re only going to remove it in the ED?” This statement indicates that:

A. the EMT does not trust the hospital staff.
B. the EMT’s focus is not on the common goal.
C. the patient’s leg does not require splinting.
D. the EMT is being realistic in her thinking.
See Effective Team Performance
cards.back: the EMT’s focus is not on the common goal.

cards.front:
If a problem with a team member is not directly or immediately impacting patient care, the team leader should:

A. discuss the problem after the call.
B. contact the medical director at once.
C. ignore the problem to avoid conflict.
D. engage the team member at once.
See Troubleshooting Team Conflicts
cards.back: discuss the problem after the call.

cards.front:
Premature diagnosis during a call can be due to what error?

A. Streamlining
B. Anchoring
C. Overconfidence
D. Bias
See Critical Thinking and Clinical Decision Making in EMS

An effective team leader should:

A. perform all difficult interventions.
B. refrain from any direct patient care.
C. help the team accomplish goals.
D. command his or her team.
See Effective Team Performance

When the EMT assists a paramedic with an advanced intervention, he or she should recall that the focus of the intervention is on:

A. completing the procedure.
B. solving a clinical problem.
C. following local protocol.
D. learning to perform the skill.
See BLS and ALS Providers Working Together

For patient handoff, it is important for EMTs and hospital staff to use:

A. common goals.
B. shared training.
C. common language.
D. metric-sized tools.
See Transfer of Patient Care

To be a great EMT, strive for:

A. foundational knowledge.
B. management work.
C. the chance to replace an EMR.
D. retraining.
See BLS and ALS Providers Working Together

Health care providers who infrequently work together can function effectively as a team if they work in an environment that supports and promotes:

A. discipline.
B. collaboration.
C. competition.
D. rigid protocols.
See Types of Teams

In an independent group, you would have:

A. a common set of tasks.
B. parallel work.
C. shared transportation.
D. your own work area.
See Dependent, Independent, and Interdependent Groups

The concept of consistent care across the entire health care team from first patient contact to patient discharge is called:

A. the scope of practice.
B. the standard of care.
C. patient care advocacy.
D. the continuum of care.
See An Era of Team Health Care

In contrast to a health care group, a health care team:

A. is not assigned specific roles.
B. works independently.
C. does not function under protocols.
D. works interdependently.
See Groups Versus Teams

The effectiveness of pit crew CPR is dependent on:

A. protocols that allow the EMT to function without medical control.
B. defining clear roles and responsibilities before the call is received.
C. rapidly assessing the patient before assigning roles and responsibilities.
D. a team leader who is capable of performing all of the patient care tasks.
See Effective Team Performance
cards.back: defining clear roles and responsibilities before the call is received.

cards.front:
Which comes first in EMS decision making?

A. Data interpretation
B. Planning
C. Data gathering
D. Team communication
See Critical Thinking and Clinical Decision Making in EMS

Which of the following would the EMT MOST likely be asked to do when assisting a paramedic with endotracheal intubation?

A. Suction under direct laryngoscopy
B. Visualization of the vocal cords
C. Placement of the endotracheal tube
D. Preoxygenation with a BVM
See BLS and ALS Providers Working Together

Which of the following would MOST likely facilitate an accurate and effective verbal handoff report at the hospital?

A. Clearly identifying your EMS certification level.
B. Brief pause in care to provide the verbal report.
C. Providing the handoff report only to a physician.
D. Use of a mutually agreed-upon handoff format.
See Transfer of Patient Care
cards.back: Use of a mutually agreed-upon handoff format.
